"While Sanchez kept quiet, his right-hand man Cesar Luena, emerged to say . . . “The party’s members are the ones that have to decide” in an extraordinary congress . . .  "Earlier, Gonzalez, party head for almost two decades, said Sanchez had promised to abstain to help facilitate a government in a private conversation after the Socialists suffered losses against Mariano Rajoy’s People’s Party in June’s election. Gonzalez told Cadena Ser radio on Wednesday. “He told me he would do one thing and then did the complete opposite.” "Ousting Sanchez may help end the nine-month deadlock that has paralyzed Spanish politics since the PP lost its majority in December when a first round of elections was held. If the rebels have their way, the party would likely appoint a temporary administrator who would then lead an abstention to let Rajoy take office. Andalusian President Susana Diaz is the most likely successor in the longer term.
. . . 
"The Socialist leader is trying to hang on until a meeting of the party’s federal committee on Saturday to present a plan to form an alternative government to Rajoy. Such a move would require support from anti-austerity group Podemos, which has captured much of the Socialist vote since emerging two years ago, as well as smaller separatist parties from Catalonia. Both alliances would sit uneasily for many Socialists.
. . . 
"Sanchez has called for the party to hold a leadership election on Oct. 23 in a bid to flush out his opponents. While senior officials are pushing for a compromise to let Rajoy take office, their leader is betting that his stance would still win the backing of the rank-and-file membership. "The pressure on Sanchez increased after the Socialists suffered losses in regional elections in Galicia and Basque Country on Sunday, falling behind Podemos in both ballots. Sanchez has posted the worst result in the Socialists’ history in both of the general elections he’s fought. Diaz, who runs the Socialists’ stronghold in southern Spain, hinted Tuesday about a challenge to Sanchez.
. . .
"Other Socialists leaders, including the regional presidents of Extremadura and Castilla-La Mancha have urged Sanchez to reconsider his stance.

A Spanish opinion poll indicates that another national election wouldn't break the political stalemate that has left the country without a government for more than nine months. The poll published Monday in El Pais showed the incumbent Popular Party slightly improving on its winning result in a repeat election last June but still short of a majority in Parliament. Without a majority, a party needs other parties' support to win a vote of confidence in Parliament before taking power. Parliament has until Oct. 31 to produce a government or a third election will be called. The Metroscopia poll was based on 1,822 interviews with voting-age people on their cellphones, with numbers generated randomly. The margin of error of the poll, conducted Sept. 6-8, was 2.3 percent.

It is instructive (for me) to review my forecasts at this point. In mid-July, I started as an optimist, believing that the PSOE cannot afford to be blamed for causing new elections and will yield, probably by a few abstentions. However, at that time I didn't know (i) about the regional elections on Sep 25, and (ii) that even if the Aug 31-Sep 2 attempt to form a government fails, there will be another chance (by Oct 31) to form a government before new elections are triggered. The turning point for me was the PSOE leadership decision to wait out the regional elections. Then I realized that a government before that will be seen as a defeat for the PSOE, so they cannot afford to allow that (unless there were a revolt, but this didn't happen).  I wonder if there will be another question on whether  a government will be formed by October 31. I believe this will depend on the PSOE showing in the Galicia/Basque country elections. A strong showing may tempt them to go for new national elections, even though this will be a risky decision. A weak showing should normally force them to acquiesce and allow 11 abstentions. But this may be the end of Sanchez and others as leaders, so they may fight it.

Mariano Rajoy, the caretaker leader of a country without a government for over eight months, lost a second vote of confidence in parliament on Friday, with lawmakers once again rejecting his bid for a new term as Spain’s prime minister. The conservative leader’s defeat, by a vote of 180 to 170, set the clock ticking toward an Oct. 31 deadline for parliament to either choose a prime minister or be dissolved for new elections, Spain’s third since December.

http://www.wsj.com/articles/spains-rajoy-braces-for-second-confidence-vote-in-parliament-1472816776 Rajoy lost again by the same margin as on Sunday.  It looks like Spain is on to a 3rd vote, probably on Christmas.

No abstentions: no government.  Small window remains for the last week of September, after the regional elections, but negotiations can continue until the deadline at the end of October.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-spain-politics-idUSKCN1181AB?il=0
This article offers an excellent up close look at why I changed my forecast so dramatically. http://www.buenosairesherald.com/article/220772/spain%E2%80%99s-socialists-say-no-to-rajoy-as-pm

Next election will be on Christmas day if a bill isn't passed to avoid that.  Rajoy is sort of holding Christmas hostage to try to scare somebody--anybody--into abstaining in the next vote.  If that doesn't work, PP will probably let the law change go through, but who knows?
Silly me. I underestimated the ability of politician to be politician.

If I am not mistaken, Sep 2 is not the last chance to vote a government in and avoid elections - that deadline is October 31. The PSOE will have another chance after the regional elections in late September - and if things go badly for them, indeed an abstention of a few MPs can be the way to go. But now - as the PSOE leadership has made the decision to wait for the regional elections and not allow a Rajoy government meanwhile - wouldn't an abstention that allows a PP/Ciudadanos government in be seen as a defeat of Sanchez and the whole leadership? It may still happen, but are the chances large?
Friday second vote. Should work. Only a few extra votes needed. Under pressure everything becomes fluid.

Per this excellent comment https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/314958 Plenty of PSOE lawmakers won't fancying a new election that is likely to be blamed on their intransigence. The vote on Friday just needs a simple majority, so 11 abstentions required. (For context, PSOE have 85 seats).
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-37237984 Rajoy et. al, got 170 votes, needed 176.  I don't see that changing in the next 48 hrs.

Socialists are pursuing a risky "no" strategy.  They are likely to lose by-elections in Galicia and Basque provinces prior to what would be a third round of elections (on 18th or 25th of December), and currently polls show that, in the event of a third election, they are running well behind their national performance in the last round of elections.    There will be good pressure on Sanchez from MPs in vulnerable districts to allow abstentions at the second investiture vote coming up this week and thus postpone new elections until the Spring of 2017 (at least), or until such time as another PP corruption scandal erupts.  For now, I am thinking there is still a 50/50 chance Sanchez allows MPs to vote their conscience and abstain if necessary.   If Sanchez votes "no" at the second investiture later this week and if the PSOE loses in the by-elections this fall, there is a very good chance someone else will be leading the PSOE at the December elections. At one time I thought there was a chance of a Ciudadanos-led minority government  if Rajoy failed at the second investiture (as it is Rajoy himself who seems to be the stumbling block for Sanchez), but the PP is doing well enough in the polls where I don't see them agreeing to this.

Spain's acting Prime Minister, Mariano Rajoy, has lost a parliamentary bid for a second term in office.
The failure to secure the position deepens the country's political crisis after two inconclusive elections.
Mr Rajoy, leader of the conservative Popular Party (PP), secured the backing of 170 representatives in the 350-strong assembly after failing to win support from the opposition. The loss increases the likelihood of a third election within a year. Mr Rajoy could still become prime minister in a second vote on Friday, in which a simple majority is needed. But this would require one or more of the other parties to abstain. (BBC)

Mariano Rajoy, Spain’s caretaker prime minister, called on opposition parties on Tuesday to allow him to form a new government or risk jeopardizing Spain’s democratic system and economic recovery.Presenting his government program before Parliament, Mr. Rajoy said that Spain faced one of the most critical challenges of its four decades of modern democracy and could not afford to prolong a political deadlock that has already produced two inconclusive elections since last December. “I can hardly imagine greater damage for Spanish democracy than telling citizens that their vote was useless in two elections and that they have to repeat general elections for the third time,” Mr. Rajoy said. “Spain urgently needs an efficient government.”Few in Spain, however, consider his chances of forming one to be very good. At best, it seems that Mr. Rajoy could emerge from this week with a vulnerable minority government.Failing that, to the exasperation of most voters, Spain is expected to hold a third general election, with voting already scheduled for Christmas Day, a prospect El País, Spain’s main newspaper, called “an unmitigated disaster.”

The end date can't be changed when the end date is part of the question stem (or when the end date is an element of the question]). So if there is no vote by 1 October, this closes. Additionally, there is a section in the GJOpen Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) that addresses this issue in more detail:https://www.gjopen.com/faq#faq11." From the Question Resolution FAQ: "11. It looks like the event may occur after the closing date of the question. How do yourself handle this? If the question itself specifies a deadline (i.e. Will North Korea conduct a missile test before 1 January 2016) then events that occur after the deadline will not count. Some questions do not include a specific deadline; in those cases, we set a likely closing date. For example, questions about election outcomes often have a provisional end date set to coincide with the election date. However, if the question is not resolved by then (e.g., parties take additional time to negotiate before naming a Prime Minister) the end date can, and will, be pushed back. Moreover, they can chose the time and manner of the demise of the minority government (as it would need Socialist support in a confidence vote).   There is bound to be another PP scandal in the press- give Rajoy his rope.    (Note that for his part, Rajoy is happy to go to a third round, particularly if the Socialists look like the bad guys and he looks more like a statesman for agreeing the pact with Citizens and consenting to some mild anti-corruption measures and judicial reform).

http://www.reuters.com/article/spain-politics-idUSL8N1AR3LL  Ciudadanos opens door to supporting Rajoy as PM " . . . Rajoy said on Wednesday his conservative People's Party would hold a leadership vote next week on a reform pact proposed by centrists Ciudadanos as a condition of their support to form a long-awaited government. . . . [An] agreement . . .  would mark the biggest step yet in ending a near eight-month political morass. Until now Ciudadanos had said only that it would abstain in any parliamentary confidence vote to install Rajoy as prime minister. "Though the PP would still need support from other forces to form a stable government and press on with an economic recovery, a shift from Ciudadanos, Spain's fourth-biggest party, could encourage others to ease objections to a conservative government. "Rajoy told a news conference that the Executive Committee - a body of about 100 people largely loyal to Rajoy - would vote on Aug. 17 on whether to back a six-point political reform package proposed on Tuesday by Ciudadanos leader Albert Rivera. . . . 
The reforms could yet prove unpalatable for PP leaders, given they are aimed at tackling corruption scandals that have tainted their party, and at changing an electoral system that benefits larger forces. But without an agreement, Spain may have little option but to hold its third election in a year. "With support from Cuidadanos, a natural ally for the PP on economic matters, Rajoy would still be seven seats shy of the 176 he needs in the 350-strong lower house of parliament for an absolute majority. Their endorsement would, however, pile more pressure on the second-placed Socialists to abstain in a confidence vote or be blamed for worsening the deadlock as worries rise over its impact on Spain's strong economic recovery.
. . ..
"Rajoy has yet to commit to a confidence vote, despite accepting a mandate from the king last month to form a government.
He declined to specify a date for the vote beyond saying he hoped to have a government in place that can deliver a budget to parliament before the end of September. "Rivera said he hoped the confidence vote would take place either in August or in early September.
~~~~~~~

Spain's liberal Ciudadanos party said on Tuesday it was open to supporting a conservative-led administration if acting Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy agreed first to a package of political reforms. The leader of Spain's Ciudadanos party said on Wednesday that acting Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy would hold a party vote in the "next few days" on a reform pact in exchange for their support to form a government. The Socialists’ 85 lawmakers in the 350-seat lower chamber have the king-maker role to break the seven-month political deadlock because an eventual agreement between Rajoy’s People’s Party and the pro-market Ciudadanos still would leave the acting premier short of a majority by at least seven votes. Nationalist parties from the Basque Country and Catalonia have refused to provide any support to Rajoy.

MADRID — Spain’s political parties have not come to an agreement on creating a coalition government that would end seven months of political deadlock, the country’s acting prime minister said on Wednesday, potentially forcing an unprecedented third round of national elections. Last week, King Felipe VI of Spain asked the acting premier, Mariano Rajoy, to form a new government, setting off a harried week of meetings with party leaders to try to create a coalition between parties that have never before joined forces in government.

The date for the vote has yet to be set.

Current deadlock in negotiations might make it less likely that a PM will win a confidence vote by October. However, the alternatives and potential benefits to all the parties of putting a stable government in place may outweigh this. Podemos failed to gain as much support as they had hoped in the last elections and some suggest that they are losing momentum; the last thing they want now is another election which, if they are blamed for the current deadlock, could even see them go backwards. The socialists want to gain the upper hand on Podemos, but tend to consider that their best chance of doing so may come in a few months time (following a solid record of attacking a potential centre-right minority government) rather than now. And the Popular Party believe they have a right to govern as a minority, so are likely to seek a vote-by-vote agreement with other parties.  The current situation makes a resolution more urgent: following the Brexit vote, the last thing Spain's fragile economy needs is more uncertainty. For the same reason, there is also likely to be behind-the-scenes pressure from the Spanish King and other European leaders for a resolution to the situation. The most probable outcome would seem to be a PM from the Popular Party (not necessarily Rajoy - the Socialists have hinted that they might give qualified support to the PP if Rajoy steps down) with a temporary mandate to govern, perhaps until further elections can be held. For this reason, I am revising my prediction up slightly. If Spain still has no government in a week, it may be worth revisiting the prediction and possibly revising down, depending on the atmosphere of the negotiations.

It is unlikely that the upcoming elections will give any single party an absolute majority (although there are some who are predicting this). However, with the centre-right Popular Party declining in popularity (ironically...), a left-wing bloc could well command close to 50% support. The left-wing parties are much more likely  than the right-wing PP to do a deal with the Catalan and/or Basque nationalist parties, which *could* give them enough support for a working government (albeit at some cost - the nationalists are likely to drive a hard bargain, and are less concerned than the others about the political process stalling, since this ultimately aids their cause).  It is also possible that the centrist 'Ciudadanos' party may hold the balance of power. They have been polling a solid 15% of late, and have some momentum. Importantly, 'Ciudadanos' may countenance a political alliance with either the left-bloc, or with the PP, making the formation of a government more likely still. Both Left and Right would probably rather bring C's in to the government than the nationalists (and C's are likely to have many more seats, and so make more useful coalition partners). Moreover, all the main leaders have acknowledged that another election is the least desirable option. Spain effectively 'shuts down' for August - businesses close, and many Spaniards go on holiday. An election during this month would be very unlikely. That means that, if there is to be another election in the short term, it would have to take place in July; coming so soon after the previous poll, this would be unlikely to produce a better outcome. The formation of a government (and, therefore, a successful vote of confidence) seems the most likely outcome at this stage. However, Spanish politics is notoriously unpredictable. Podemos, moreover, has no record in government, and significant ideological dissonance on the Left may be enough to stall a deal, especially if it is not struck quickly. The nationalist element is also important here - both Left and Right have deep-seated anxieties about the nationalist parties, and any attempt to include them in a government may be enough to ignite wider tensions. The longer negotiations take, the more likely it is that a vote of confidence would fail, especially if public opinion seems to be turning against the Left; therefore, I will consider revising this prediction down in a week if no government has been successfully formed by then.

For this reason, we should expect Spain to be able to form a new government after these elections. https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/monkey-cage/wp/2016/06/22/snap-will-spain-finally-form-a-government-after-its-june-26-election-do-over/ Podemos, IU and several other minor left-wing parties have now formed an alliance called Unidos Podemos (United We Can), which they hope to establish as the main alternative to the right-wing PP. As it stands, the polls (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_Spanish_general_election,_2016) predict results similar to the December 2015 election albeit with the the Podemos led alliance in second place, instead of PSOE. This means no party has enough to form a government on its own, and more importantly no two left parties or right parties (categorizing Cuidadanos as right since they are to the right of Podemos and PSOE) have enough to form a government together. This leaves two possibilities:

1- Things change in the next two weeks and either the left or the right "surges" ahead to get more than 50% of the seats. Let's assign this event a 40% chance.  If it's the right surging ahead (20% of the total), I think it would be easier for PP and Cuidadanos to either form a coalition or to have a PP government propped up by Cuidadanos (15% of the total). Otherwise if it's the left surging ahead (20%), it could be a little harder since chances are PSOE will have to be the junior partner unless Podemos concedes (10%? of the total). In short, while I'm assigning a 40% chance of a left or right tilt, I'm only assigning a 25% chance that this leads to a government.  2- Things stay the same and neither the left nor right surges (60%). Then, it's tough. Will they repeat the election a third time? I would say that's unpalatable to all parties involved. On the other hand, there is no way that the right coalition supports a Podemos led government (1%). It is also hard to imagine that the PSOE would be allowed to form a government as the third place finishers (2%).   Would the PSOE join a PP led government? or would they support it (PP or PP/C's) from the outside? That was a non-starter with the current prime minister, but could they change their minds, or could the PP's have a leadership coup to change the prime-minister and facilitate forming a government (10%)? Summing things up, I'm at 25+1+2+10, and let's round up to 40 for good measure, and to account for the fact that there would be pressure to form a government. I'm anticipating going up further as more polls come in, because it is possible that people may vote strategically for their second choice to avoid a third election.

So far the polls are showing PP with the lead, but not by enough to get in without help.  PSOE are becoming increasingly irrelevant, it seems.  Starting fairly low, but I'm prepared to move as quickly as I can at my age if things start to move.
